How many grams of NaCl will be produced if 17.5 g of Na react with excess Cl2 based on the following balanced equation: 

2 Na + Cl2 â†’ 2 NaCl
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the stoichiometry method. First, we need to find the molar mass of Na and NaCl.

The molar mass of Na (sodium) is approximately 23 g/mol.
The molar mass of NaCl (sodium chloride) is approximately 58.44 g/mol (23 g/mol for Na + 35.45 g/mol for Cl).

Now, we will convert the given mass of Na (17.5 g) to moles:

moles of Na = mass of Na / molar mass of Na
moles of Na = 17.5 g / 23 g/mol = 0.76087 mol

According to the balanced equation, 2 moles of Na react with Cl2 to produce 2 moles of NaCl. So, the mole ratio of Na to NaCl is 1:1.

moles of NaCl = moles of Na (since the mole ratio is 1:1)
moles of NaCl = 0.76087 mol

Now, we will convert the moles of NaCl to grams:

mass of NaCl = moles of NaCl * molar mass of NaCl
mass of NaCl = 0.76087 mol * 58.44 g/mol = 44.45 g

Therefore, 44.45 grams of NaCl will be produced if 17.5 g of Na react with excess Cl2.
